McTaggart, Alfred,
Windthorst,
To Sask., August, 1901.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experience; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. If there should be any question in your mind as to whether or not to answer a particular event, if they help to answer the questions, then answer them. This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1874, and easy to answer or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Saskatchewan Archives
No. 2

Western Canadian Pioneers Experiences will be answered this year and will be sent to the Saskatchewan Archives Office at the University of Saskatchewan, please send your copy.

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual wishes to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experience; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. If there are insufficient space to answer the question, write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1870 and have personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

NO. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A copy of questionnaire to the person

ANSWERING THIS QUESTIONNAIRE

It is difficult to create a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove inappropriate for you to answer, so don't worry about answering blank spaces. Use "Ex" in the spaces of reply if there is not sufficient space to answer the question. Don't write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write together. This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer life, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Western Canadian Pioneers East is still being completed. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives questions on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

(X) All questionnaires
    Pioneer health conditions
    Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
    Pioneer housing
    Pioneer education and employment
    Pioneer farming experience

Expressation of Questionnaire

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent records of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
McTaggart, Alfred,
Winthorpe.

To Sask. - August, 1901.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

NO. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is important to prepare a general questionnaire on Pioneer Life before any individual who lives here will not apply to your knowledge blank spaces. The answers should be given in detail, or there is no sufficient basis to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1875, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or supply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Days: That Said Saskatchewan Pioneer Days," is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent records of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name .................................................. Alfred McTaggart

2. Your address .................................................. Windthorst, Saskatchewan

3. Date ................................................................. May 31st, 1932

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)
   Near Exeter, Huron County, Ontario.

5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   Alfred McTaggart—Farmer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
   August 1901

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
   None

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc).
   25 yrs.

9. What were your reasons for coming West? To seek my fortune.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?).
    Through other people

   Accepted as the usual thing at that time.

   C.P.R. Railway

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.).
   When the Reston-Wolseley branch was being built I came to Windthorst in August 1906 and was the first settler on the town-site. No roads at that time only prairie trails.

29. How often did you shop in the early days? weekly on Saturday.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays? about 1915.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible. Only in local organizations.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)
   I am a Charter member of the Masonic Lodge.
   I was a member of the first firm to do business in Windthorst.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given (5) date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).
   Windthorst - from a German statesman of Bismarck's time.

School Districts:
   Buffalo Plains a level tract at foot of Moose Mountain
   Mount Murray from a cone shaped hill close to school on land owned by a man named Murray.
   Crocus from the prairie flower.
   Coronation School built the year of the coronation of George Vth.
   Rhine land German settlement with old country memories
5. Did many people move away during the years 1914-1918?

Yes. No.

6. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

7. If you or any of your family or friends were drafted to have or do something in the military service, explain it here. Giving dates whenever possible, (such as coming in the call-up, enlistment, etc.)

In the call-up I enlisted on June 23rd, organizing the first Legion unit, I was a charter member of the local Legion, and I was a member of the first firm to do business in Windthorst.

8. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give (1) name and occupation of person (2) date and reason for change, (3) date and reason for change, (4) date and reason for change.

Windthorst - from a German statesman or Bishop's name.

School Districts: Plains a level tract at foot of Morse Mountain, Murray - from a man named Murray.

Coronation School built the year of the coronation of George V.

Rhine Land - German settlement with old happy memories.
